contents.title: Installation
contents.description: tRPC-Nuxt provides first class integration with tRPC.

props.code: pnpm add @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod
npm install @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod
yarn add @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod

children.value: For implementing tRPC endpoints and routers.
For making typesafe API calls from your client.
for input validation and tRPC.io highly recommends it, though it isn't required.
If you want to use Zod for input validation, make sure you have enabled strict mode:
If strict mode is too much, at least enable
Now that you've installed the required dependencies, you are ready to start building your application.

props.code: pnpm add @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod
npm install @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod
yarn add @trpc/server@next @trpc/client@next trpc-nuxt@beta zod

children.value: For implementing tRPC endpoints and routers.
For making typesafe API calls from your client.
for input validation and tRPC.io highly recommends it, though it isn't required.
If you want to use Zod for input validation, make sure you have enabled strict mode:
If strict mode is too much, at least enable
Now that you've installed the required dependencies, you are ready to start building your application.

contents.title: Usage
contents.description: tRPC-Nuxt provides first class integration with tRPC.

children.value: Recommended but not enforced file structure. This is what you get when starting from

props.code:
.
├── server
│   ├── api
│   │   └── trpc
│   │       └── [trpc].ts  # <-- tRPC HTTP handler
│   │   └── [..]
│   ├── trpc
│   │   ├── routers
│   │   │   ├── index.ts  # <-- main app router
│   │   │   ├── todo.ts  # <-- sub routers
│   │   │   └── [..]
│   │   ├── context.ts   # <-- create app context
│   │   └── trpc.ts      # <-- procedure helpers
├── plugins
│   ├── client.ts  # <-- tRPC Client as a plugin
└── [..]

children.value:

Initialize your tRPC backend using the
function and create your first router.
// Avoid exporting the entire t-object since it's not very
// descriptive and can be confusing to newcomers used to t
If you need to split your router into several subrouters, you can implement them in the
Create a set of strongly-typed composables using your API's type signature.
* If you want to use SSR, you need to use the server's full URL
// query and mutate uses useAsyncData under the hood

contents.title: tRPC Nuxt

children.value: End-to-end typesafe APIs in Nuxt applications.
